thread.title: 3 alternate stats that favor Falcons in Super Bowl
thread.title_full: 3 alternate stats that favor Falcons in Super Bowl

author: AJC Sports
title: 3 alternate stats that favor Falcons in Super Bowl
text:
From the NFL Network‚Äôs ‚ÄúGood Morning Football‚Äù show, here are three negative stats with an alternate twist that favor the Atlanta Falcons against the New England Patriots in the Super Bowl.
¬ª Shanahan loses game plan at Opening Night
¬ª Photos: Falcons in spotlight at Opening Night
¬ª Jones, Mack don‚Äôt practice in Houston
1. Playoff puzzle Falcons quarterback Matt Ryan has thrown for seven touchdowns this postseason. Curtis Compton / ccompton@ajc.com ‚Ä¢ The stat: The Falcons‚Äô Matt Ryan is the first NFL quarterback with a losing playoff record (3-4) to reach the Super Bowl.
‚Ä¢ The alternate stat: Ryan is the fourth quarterback in NFL history to reach the Super Bowl while throwing six or more touchdowns and no interceptions in the playoffs. The three other players -- Joe Flacco (2012), Drew Brees (2009) and Joe Montana (1989) -- won the Super Bowl.
2. The Belichick wall ‚Ä¢ The stat: Since 2010, coaches facing New England‚Äôs Bill Belichick for the first time are 3-22. The Falcons‚Äô Dan Quinn is facing Belichick for the first time as a head coach on Sunday.
#SB51 will be the first time Dan Quinn faces Bill Belichick as a head coach. üëÄ pic.twitter.com/6kZ95SFf8d
‚Äî NFL Network (@nflnetwork) January 31, 2017 ‚Ä¢ The alternate stat: Quinn is appearing in his third Super Bowl in four years. (Quinn‚Äôs two previous appearances were as Seattle‚Äôs defensive end.) The last coach to appear in three of four Super Bowls was Belichick.
3. The not-so-mighty Brady Tom Brady threw for three touchdowns against the Pittsburgh Steelers in the AFC Championship Game. Elsa/Getty Images ‚Ä¢ The stat: Tom Brady is playing for his record fifth Super Bowl title.
‚Ä¢ The alternate stat: Brady is 1-2, following a playoff game in which he has thrown 3 touchdowns and 0 interceptions. Brady had 3 touchdowns and 0 interceptions in the New England‚Äôs win over Pittsburgh in the AFC Championship Game.
Falcons wide receiver Julio Jones discusses the receivers in the NFL and his role with the team. Video by D. Orlando Ledbetter
